newsitem.title: USA: Republican divisions won't derail budget - Clinton.
newsitem.headline: Republican divisions won't derail budget - Clinton.

text.p: President Clinton said on Sunday that he does expect divisions among Republican lawmakers to derail a balanced budget deal.
"I do not expect that to be prohibitive," Clinton told a news conference after the close of the summit of industrial nations here.
House Speaker Newt Gingrich has come in for criticism recently from some other Republican lawmakers for the way he handled a bill to provide disaster aid to North and South Dakota and other states.
Clinton voiced a variety of concerns about Senate proposals to force affluent seniors to pay more under the government's Medicare health plan and to raise the eligibility age under the program.
Democrats and Rrepublicans on the Senate Finance Committee last week unanimously approved wide-ranging budget legislation that includes that provision.
Clinton said that such proposals were outside the confines of the broad balanced budget deal he has struck with Congress and noted that agreement already contains cost-savings for Medicare.
He also questioned whether a gradual increase in the eligibility age for Medicare to 67 from 65 would leave some seniors without health coverage.
"Philosophically I (am) not opposed to means testing Medicare," Clinton added. But he said that such a proposal might make it more difficult to pass a detailed balanced budget agreement in the House.
